ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided a fascinating overview into the ways in which Greeks and Romans thought about their environment. Each week was organized thematically (from animals to pollution).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Not all readings felt necessary or were discussed in class, which was fine, though it might have been better to classify some as required and others as supplemental. Otherwise, the teaching was great, in-class discussions were always lively, and deep dives from individual classmates provided a good way to engage with the material from ones own area of expertise.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I hope undergrads take this as a lecture in the spring. Even if Classics isnt your thing, there are a lot of parallels with more contemporary times, and you dont need as much context as with many other classical works to understand the readings here. Moreover, there are so many ways to engage with the readings from different perspectives, including philosophy, art history, and even science.
Yes! Very interesting way into the authors and texts and themes
